Class JsHTMLInputElement

All Implemented Interfaces:
EventTarget, ObjectLike
Direct Known Subclasses:
DOM2HTML.HTMLButtonElement.Prototype, DOM2HTML.HTMLCheckBoxElement.Prototype, DOM2HTML.HTMLFileUploadElement.Prototype, DOM2HTML.HTMLHiddenElement.Prototype, DOM2HTML.HTMLImageElement.Prototype, DOM2HTML.HTMLPasswordElement.Prototype, DOM2HTML.HTMLRadioElement.Prototype, DOM2HTML.HTMLResetElement.Prototype, DOM2HTML.HTMLSubmitElement.Prototype, DOM2HTML.HTMLTextFieldElement.Prototype
public class JsHTMLInputElement
extends DOM2HTML.HTMLInputElement.Prototype

An opaque class representing JavaScript client-side objects of the global JsClient.HTMLInputElement class.

This class represents a form control in an HTML page, or a JsHTMLElement object created with the HTML <input> tag.

The three most important properties of a JsHTMLInputElement object are type, value, and name.

The legal values of type and the corresponding opaque subclass of JsHTMLInputElement are:

  • "button": JsHTMLButtonElement
  • "checkbox": JsHTMLCheckBoxElement
  • "file": JsHTMLFileUploadElement
  • "hidden": JsHTMLHiddenElement
  • "image": JsHTMLImageElement
  • "password": JsHTMLPasswordElement
  • "radio": JsHTMLRadioElement
  • "reset": JsHTMLResetElement
  • "submit": JsHTMLSubmitElement
  • "text": JsHTMLTextFieldElement

Author:
J.J.Liu (Jianjun Liu) at http://www.jscripter.org
JavaScript:
Opaque types can be resolved but no class objects for them can be generated into the target codes. Re-compilers must exit with error on the operations of accessing that kind of class objects. The checkcast operation to the class literal of this interface must be ignored and instanceof to it always true.

Field Detail

form

public static final JsHTMLFormElement.Member form

An opaque static field defining a member that is named by the field name without a qualifying member and to access the property of the name on an object.

The property, identified by this member, of a JsHTMLInputElement object is a read-only reference to the JsHTMLFormElement object containing the control. It is null if the control is not within the context of a form.

Since:
1.0
JavaScript:
Re-compilers must resolve the member of this static field to the identifier of the field name.

accept

public static final Value.String.Member accept

An opaque static field defining a member that is named by the field name without a qualifying member and to access the property of the name on an object.

The property, identified by this member, of a JsHTMLInputElement object refers to a string that mirrors the accept attribute of the image element. When type is "file", the property is a comma-separated list of MIME types specifying the types of files that may be uploaded to and handled correctly by the server processing the form.

Since:
1.0
JavaScript:
Re-compilers must resolve the member of this static field to the identifier of the field name.

accessKey

public static final Value.String.Member accessKey

An opaque static field defining a member that is named by the field name without a qualifying member and to access the property of the name on an object.

The property, identified by this member, of a JsHTMLInputElement object refers to a string specifying single character access key to the element. An access key is a single character from the document character set. Pressing an access key assigned to an element gives focus to the element. The action that occurs when an element receives focus depends on the element.

Since:
1.0
JavaScript:
Re-compilers must resolve the member of this static field to the identifier of the field name.

align

public static final Value.String.Member align

An opaque static field defining a member that is named by the field name without a qualifying member and to access the property of the name on an object.

The property, identified by this member, of a JsHTMLInputElement object refers to a string specifying the horizontal alignment of the element with respect to the surrounding context. Possible values are:

  • "left": text lines are rendered flush left.
  • "center": text lines are centered.
  • "right": text lines are rendered flush right.
  • "justify": text lines are justified to both margins.
The default value of this attribute depends on the base text direction. For left to right text, the default is "left", while for right to left text, it is "right".

This attribute is deprecated by HTML 4.01 and should be handled by style sheets.

Since:
1.0
JavaScript:
Re-compilers must resolve the member of this static field to the identifier of the field name.

alt

public static final Value.String.Member alt

An opaque static field defining a member that is named by the field name without a qualifying member and to access the property of the name on an object.

The property, identified by this member, of a JsHTMLInputElement object refers to a string specifying an alternate text for web browsers not rendering the normal content of this element.

Since:
1.0
JavaScript:
Re-compilers must resolve the member of this static field to the identifier of the field name.

defaultValue

public static final Value.String.Member defaultValue

An opaque static field defining a member that is named by the field name without a qualifying member and to access the property of the name on an object.

The property, identified by this member, of a JsHTMLInputElement object refers to a string that holds the initial value displayed by the element when type is "text", "password" or "file". When the form is reset, the element is restored to this value. Changing the value of this property also changes the value property and the currently displayed value. The value of the property does not change if the contents of the corresponding form control, in an interactive browser, changes.

Since:
1.0
JavaScript:
Re-compilers must resolve the member of this static field to the identifier of the field name.

public static final Value.Number.Member maxLength

An opaque static field defining a member that is named by the field name without a qualifying member and to access the property of the name on an object.

The property, identified by this member, of a JsHTMLInputElement object refers to a numeric value that specifies the maximum number of characters that the user is allowed to enter in the text field when type is "text" or "password".

Since:
1.0
JavaScript:
Re-compilers must resolve the member of this static field to the identifier of the field name.

public static final Value.String.Member name

An opaque static field defining a member that is named by the field name without a qualifying member and to access the property of the name on an object.

The property, identified by this member, of a JsHTMLInputElement object refers to a string specifying the name of the input control when submitted with the form.

Since:
1.0

size

public static final Value.Number.Member size

An opaque static field defining a member that is named by the field name without a qualifying member and to access the property of the name on an object.

The property, identified by this member, of a JsHTMLInputElement object refers to an integer value that designates the initial width of the control. The width is given in pixels except when type attribute has the value "text" or "password". In that case, its value refers to the number of characters.

Since:
1.0
JavaScript:
Re-compilers must resolve the member of this static field to the identifier of the field name.

An opaque static field defining a member that is named by the field name without a qualifying member and to access the property of the name on an object.

The property, identified by this member, of a JsHTMLInputElement object refers to a string specifying the URL of the image to be used to decorate the graphical submit button when type is "image".

Since:
1.0

The property, identified by this member, of a JsHTMLInputElement object refers to an index number representing the element's position in the tabbing order.

type

public static final Value.String.Member type

An opaque static field defining a member that is named by the field name without a qualifying member and to access the property of the name on an object.

The property, identified by this member, of a JsHTMLInputElement object refers to a string specifying the type of the input element. Possible values are: "text", "password", "checkbox", "radio", "submit", "reset", "file", "hidden", "image" or "button". The default value is "text".

Since:
1.0
JavaScript:
Re-compilers must resolve the member of this static field to the identifier of the field name.

public static final Value.String.Member useMap

An opaque static field defining a member that is named by the field name without a qualifying member and to access the property of the name on an object.

The property, identified by this member, of a JsHTMLInputElement object refers to a string specifying a client-side image map for the image when type is "image".

Since:
1.0
JavaScript:
Re-compilers must resolve the member of this static field to the identifier of the field name.

value

public static final Value.String.Member value

An opaque static field defining a member that is named by the field name without a qualifying member and to access the property of the name on an object.

The property, identified by this member, of a JsHTMLInputElement object refers to a string value that is passed to the web server when the form is submitted. If type is "text", "password", or "file", the property is the editable text contents contained by the input element. If type is "button", "submit", or "reset", the property is the non-editable label that appears in the button. For security reasons, the value property of JsHTMLFileUploadElement may be read-only. Similarly, this property for JsHTMLPasswordElement may not contain the user's actual input.

Since:
1.0
JavaScript:
Re-compilers must resolve the member of this static field to the identifier of the field name.

checked

public static final Value.Boolean.Member checked

An opaque static field defining a member that is named by the field name without a qualifying member and to access the property of the name on an object.

The property, identified by this member, of a JsHTMLInputElement object refers to a boolean value that specifies whether the element is "checked" or not, mirroring the "checked" attribute of the HTML input element, if type is "radio" or "checkbox". Setting this property changes the visual appearance of the element.

Since:
1.0
JavaScript:
Re-compilers must resolve the member of this static field to the identifier of the field name.

defaultChecked

public static final Value.Boolean.Member defaultChecked

An opaque static field defining a member that is named by the field name without a qualifying member and to access the property of the name on an object.

The property, identified by this member, of a JsHTMLInputElement object refers to a string that holds the initial value of the checked attribute as it appears in the document source, when type is "radio" or "checkbox". When the form is reset, the checked property is restored to this value. Changing the value of this property also changes the checked property and the current checked state of the control element. The value of this property does not change if the state of the corresponding form control, in an interactive browser, changes.

Since:
1.0
JavaScript:
Re-compilers must resolve the member of this static field to the identifier of the field name.

public static final Value.Boolean.Member disabled

An opaque static field defining a member that is named by the field name without a qualifying member and to access the property of the name on an object.

The property, identified by this member, of a JsHTMLInputElement object refers to a boolean value that specifies whether the element is disabled and is unavailable for user input.

Since:
1.0
JavaScript:
Re-compilers must resolve the member of this static field to the identifier of the field name.

readOnly

public static final Value.Boolean.Member readOnly

An opaque static field defining a member that is named by the field name without a qualifying member and to access the property of the name on an object.

The property, identified by this member, of a JsHTMLInputElement object refers to a boolean value that specifies whether the input control is read-only. Relevant only when type has the value "text" or "password".

Since:
1.0
JavaScript:
Re-compilers must resolve the member of this static field to the identifier of the field name.

onblur

public static final JsFunction.Member<?> onblur

An opaque static field defining a member that is named by the field name without a qualifying member and to access the property of the name on an object.

The property, identified by this member, of a JsHTMLInputElement object is a reference to an event handler function invoked when the user takes keyboard focus away from the input control element. Calling blur() to remove focus from an element does not invoke onblur for that object. Note, however, that calling focus() to transfer focus to some other element causes the onblur to be invoked for whichever element currently has the focus.

Since:
1.0
See Also:
JsElement.addEventListener(String, JsFunction, Boolean), JsElement.attachEvent(String, JsFunction)
JavaScript:
Re-compilers must resolve the member of this static field to the identifier of the field name.

onchange

public static final JsFunction.Member<?> onchange

An opaque static field defining a member that is named by the field name without a qualifying member and to access the property of the name on an object.

The property, identified by this member, of a JsHTMLInputElement object is a reference to an event handler function invoked for text-entry elements when the user changes the displayed text and then commits those changes by tabbing or clicking to transfer keyboard focus to another element. This event handler is not invoked for every keystroke in the input control but only when the user completes an edit. Toggle button elements of type "checkbox" and "radio" may also fire this event in addition to the onclick event when the user toggles them.

Since:
1.0
See Also:
JsElement.addEventListener(String, JsFunction, Boolean), JsElement.attachEvent(String, JsFunction)
JavaScript:
Re-compilers must resolve the member of this static field to the identifier of the field name.

onclick

public static final JsFunction.Member<?> onclick

An opaque static field defining a member that is named by the field name without a qualifying member and to access the property of the name on an object.

The property, identified by this member, of a JsHTMLInputElement object is a reference to an event handler function invoked for push button and toggle button elements when the user activates the button with a mouse click or by keyboard traversal. The handler is NOT invoked when the click() method is called for the element. When type is "reset" and "submit", this handler is performed in addition to the default actions of resetting and submitting respectively the form that contains the element. You can also prevent the default actions by returning false from this handler or from JsHTMLFormElement.onreset and JsHTMLFormElement.onsubmit of the form.

Since:
1.0
See Also:
JsElement.addEventListener(String, JsFunction, Boolean), JsElement.attachEvent(String, JsFunction)
JavaScript:
Re-compilers must resolve the member of this static field to the identifier of the field name.

onfocus

public static final JsFunction.Member<?> onfocus

An opaque static field defining a member that is named by the field name without a qualifying member and to access the property of the name on an object.

The property, identified by this member, of a JsHTMLInputElement object is a reference to an event handler function invoked when the user gives keyboard focus to the input control element. Calling focus() to set focus to an element does not invoke onfocus for that object. Note, however, that calling focus() to transfer focus to some other element causes the onblur to be invoked for whichever element currently has the focus.

Since:
1.0
See Also:
JsElement.addEventListener(String, JsFunction, Boolean), JsElement.attachEvent(String, JsFunction)
JavaScript:
Re-compilers must resolve the member of this static field to the identifier of the field name.

Method Detail

See Also:
Var.toString()

blur

public void blur()

Takes keyboard focus away from the input control element.

This method does not transfer keyboard focus anywhere, however, so the only time that it is actually useful to call this method is right before you transfer keyboard focus elsewhere with the focus() method, when you don't want to trigger the onblur event handler. That is, by removing focus explicitly from the element, you won't be notified when it is removed implicitly by a focus() call on another element.

Since:
1.0
JavaScript:
Re-compilers must convert the instance invocation of this method directly into a JavaScript invocation on its current object instance without changing the method name, but expanding variable arguments, if any, into comma-separated values.

click

public void click()

Simulates a mouse-click on the element if type is "button", "checkbox", "radio", "reset", or "submit".

This method is not often useful. Because it does not invoke the onclick event handler. When called on elements of type "button", they don't have any behavior other than that defined by the onclick handler. Calling the method on elements of type "submit" or "reset" submits or resets the form, but this can be more directly achieved with the JsHTMLFormElement.submit() and JsHTMLFormElement.reset() method of the form itself.

Since:
1.0
JavaScript:
Re-compilers must convert the instance invocation of this method directly into a JavaScript invocation on its current object instance without changing the method name, but expanding variable arguments, if any, into comma-separated values.

focus

public void focus()

Gives keyboard focus to this input control element.

This method makes the control element active with respect to keyboard navigation and keyboard input. If it is called for an input element of type "text", any text the user subsequently types appears in that text element. Or, if it is called for an element of type "button", the user can then invoke that button from the keyboard.

Since:
1.0
JavaScript:
Re-compilers must convert the instance invocation of this method directly into a JavaScript invocation on its current object instance without changing the method name, but expanding variable arguments, if any, into comma-separated values.

select

public void select()

Selects the text displayed by the input element if type is "file", "password", or "text".

Typically, this means that the text is highlighted and that new text entered by the user replaces the highlighted text instead of being appended or inserted to it.

Since:
1.0
JavaScript:
Re-compilers must convert the instance invocation of this method directly into a JavaScript invocation on its current object instance without changing the method name, but expanding variable arguments, if any, into comma-separated values.
